description: Retrieves the properties of a container group definition, including all container definitions in the group. If successful, this operation returns the complete properties of a container group definition version.

parameters.name: Name
parameters.description: The unique identifier for the container group definition to retrieve properties for. You can use either the Name or ARN value.

nested_items.name: ContainerGroupDefinition
nested_items.description: The properties of the requested container group definition resource.

nested_items.name: ContainerGroupDefinitionArn
nested_items.description: The Amazon Resource Name ( ARN) that is assigned to an Amazon GameLift ContainerGroupDefinition resource. It uniquely identifies the resource across all Amazon Web Services Regions. Format is arn:aws:gamelift:[region]::containergroupdefinition/[container group definition name]:[version].

nested_items.name: CreationTime
nested_items.description: A time stamp indicating when this data object was created. Format is a number expressed in Unix time as milliseconds (for example "1469498468.057").

nested_items.name: OperatingSystem
nested_items.description: The platform that all containers in the container group definition run on.

nested_items.name: Name
nested_items.description: A descriptive identifier for the container group definition. The name value is unique in an Amazon Web Services Region.

nested_items.name: ContainerGroupType
nested_items.description: The type of container group. Container group type determines how Amazon GameLift deploys the container group on each fleet instance.

nested_items.name: TotalMemoryLimitMebibytes
nested_items.description: The amount of memory (in MiB) on a fleet instance to allocate for the container group. All containers in the group share these resources.

nested_items.name: TotalVcpuLimit
nested_items.description: The amount of vCPU units on a fleet instance to allocate for the container group (1 vCPU is equal to 1024 CPU units). All containers in the group share these resources. You can set a limit for each container definition in the group. If individual containers have limits, this total value must be equal to or greater than the sum of the limits for each container in the group.

nested_items.name: GameServerContainerDefinition
nested_items.description: The definition for the game server container in this group. This property is used only when the container group type is GAME_SERVER. This container definition specifies a container image with the game server build.

nested_items.name: ContainerName
nested_items.description: The container definition identifier. Container names are unique within a container group definition.

nested_items.name: DependsOn
nested_items.description: Indicates that the container relies on the status of other containers in the same container group during startup and shutdown sequences. A container might have dependencies on multiple containers.

nested_items.name: ContainerName
nested_items.description: A descriptive label for the container definition that this container depends on.

nested_items.name: Condition
nested_items.description: The condition that the dependency container must reach before the dependent container can start. Valid conditions include:
START - The dependency container must have started.

COMPLETE - The dependency container has run to completion (exits). Use this condition with nonessential containers, such as those that run a script and then exit. The dependency container can't be an essential container.
SUCCESS - The dependency container has run to completion and exited with a zero status. The dependency container can't be an essential container.

HEALTHY - The dependency container has passed its Docker health check. Use this condition with dependency containers that have health checks configured. This condition is confirmed at container group startup only.

nested_items.name: MountPoints
nested_items.description: A mount point that binds a path inside the container to a file or directory on the host system and lets it access the file or directory.

nested_items.name: InstancePath
nested_items.description: The path to the source file or directory.

nested_items.name: ContainerPath
nested_items.description: The mount path on the container. If this property isn't set, the instance path is used.

nested_items.name: AccessLevel
nested_items.description: The type of access for the container.

nested_items.name: EnvironmentOverride
nested_items.description: A set of environment variables that's passed to the container on startup. See the ContainerDefinition::environment parameter in the Amazon Elastic Container Service API Reference.

nested_items.name: Name
nested_items.description: The environment variable name.

nested_items.name: Value
nested_items.description: The environment variable value.

nested_items.name: ImageUri
nested_items.description: The URI to the image that Amazon GameLift uses when deploying this container to a container fleet. For a more specific identifier, see ResolvedImageDigest.

nested_items.name: PortConfiguration
nested_items.description: The set of ports that are available to bind to processes in the container. For example, a game server process requires a container port to allow game clients to connect to it. Container ports aren't directly accessed by inbound traffic. Amazon GameLift maps these container ports to externally accessible connection ports, which are assigned as needed from the container fleet's ConnectionPortRange.

nested_items.name: ContainerPortRanges
nested_items.description: A set of one or more container port number ranges. The ranges can't overlap.

nested_items.name: FromPort
nested_items.description: A starting value for the range of allowed port numbers.

nested_items.name: ToPort
nested_items.description: An ending value for the range of allowed port numbers. Port numbers are end-inclusive. This value must be equal to or greater than FromPort.

nested_items.name: Protocol
nested_items.description: The network protocol that these ports support.

nested_items.name: ResolvedImageDigest
nested_items.description: A unique and immutable identifier for the container image. The digest is a SHA 256 hash of the container image manifest.

nested_items.name: ServerSdkVersion
nested_items.description: The Amazon GameLift server SDK version that the game server is integrated with. Only game servers using 5.2.0 or higher are compatible with container fleets.

nested_items.name: SupportContainerDefinitions
nested_items.description: The set of definitions for support containers in this group. A container group definition might have zero support container definitions. Support container can be used in any type of container group.

nested_items.name: ContainerName
nested_items.description: The container definition identifier. Container names are unique within a container group definition.

nested_items.name: DependsOn
nested_items.description: Indicates that the container relies on the status of other containers in the same container group during its startup and shutdown sequences. A container might have dependencies on multiple containers.

nested_items.name: ContainerName
nested_items.description: A descriptive label for the container definition that this container depends on.

nested_items.name: Condition
nested_items.description: The condition that the dependency container must reach before the dependent container can start. Valid conditions include:
START - The dependency container must have started.

COMPLETE - The dependency container has run to completion (exits). Use this condition with nonessential containers, such as those that run a script and then exit. The dependency container can't be an essential container.
SUCCESS - The dependency container has run to completion and exited with a zero status. The dependency container can't be an essential container.

HEALTHY - The dependency container has passed its Docker health check. Use this condition with dependency containers that have health checks configured. This condition is confirmed at container group startup only.

nested_items.name: MountPoints
nested_items.description: A mount point that binds a path inside the container to a file or directory on the host system and lets it access the file or directory.

nested_items.name: InstancePath
nested_items.description: The path to the source file or directory.

nested_items.name: ContainerPath
nested_items.description: The mount path on the container. If this property isn't set, the instance path is used.

nested_items.name: AccessLevel
nested_items.description: The type of access for the container.

nested_items.name: EnvironmentOverride
nested_items.description: A set of environment variables that's passed to the container on startup. See the ContainerDefinition::environment parameter in the Amazon Elastic Container Service API Reference.

nested_items.name: Name
nested_items.description: The environment variable name.

nested_items.name: Value
nested_items.description: The environment variable value.

nested_items.name: Essential
nested_items.description: Indicates whether the container is vital to the container group. If an essential container fails, the entire container group restarts.

nested_items.name: HealthCheck
nested_items.description: A configuration for a non-terminal health check. A support container automatically restarts if it stops functioning or if it fails this health check.

nested_items.name: Command
nested_items.description: A string array that specifies the command that the container runs to determine if it's healthy.
(string) ---

nested_items.name: Interval
nested_items.description: The time period (in seconds) between each health check.

nested_items.name: Retries
nested_items.description: The number of times to retry a failed health check before flagging the container unhealthy. The first run of the command does not count as a retry.

nested_items.name: StartPeriod
nested_items.description: The optional grace period (in seconds) to give a container time to bootstrap before the first failed health check counts toward the number of retries.

nested_items.name: Timeout
nested_items.description: The time period (in seconds) to wait for a health check to succeed before counting a failed health check.

nested_items.name: ImageUri
nested_items.description: The URI to the image that Amazon GameLift deploys to a container fleet. For a more specific identifier, see ResolvedImageDigest.

nested_items.name: MemoryHardLimitMebibytes
nested_items.description: The amount of memory that Amazon GameLift makes available to the container. If memory limits aren't set for an individual container, the container shares the container group's total memory allocation.

nested_items.name: PortConfiguration
nested_items.description: A set of ports that allow access to the container from external users. Processes running in the container can bind to a one of these ports. Container ports aren't directly accessed by inbound traffic. Amazon GameLift maps these container ports to externally accessible connection ports, which are assigned as needed from the container fleet's ConnectionPortRange.

nested_items.name: ContainerPortRanges
nested_items.description: A set of one or more container port number ranges. The ranges can't overlap.

nested_items.name: FromPort
nested_items.description: A starting value for the range of allowed port numbers.

nested_items.name: ToPort
nested_items.description: An ending value for the range of allowed port numbers. Port numbers are end-inclusive. This value must be equal to or greater than FromPort.

nested_items.name: Protocol
nested_items.description: The network protocol that these ports support.

nested_items.name: ResolvedImageDigest
nested_items.description: A unique and immutable identifier for the container image. The digest is a SHA 256 hash of the container image manifest.

nested_items.name: Vcpu
nested_items.description: The number of vCPU units that are reserved for the container. If no resources are reserved, the container shares the total vCPU limit for the container group.

nested_items.name: VersionNumber
nested_items.description: Indicates the version of a particular container group definition. This number is incremented automatically when you update a container group definition. You can view, update, or delete individual versions or the entire container group definition.

nested_items.name: VersionDescription
nested_items.description: An optional description that was provided for a container group definition update. Each version can have a unique description.

nested_items.name: Status
nested_items.description: Current status of the container group definition resource. Values include:
COPYING --- Amazon GameLift is in the process of making copies of all container images that are defined in the group. While in this state, the resource can't be used to create a container fleet.
READY --- Amazon GameLift has copied the registry images for all containers that are defined in the group. You can use a container group definition in this status to create a container fleet.

FAILED --- Amazon GameLift failed to create a valid container group definition resource. For more details on the cause of the failure, see StatusReason. A container group definition resource in failed status will be deleted within a few minutes.

nested_items.name: StatusReason
nested_items.description: Additional information about a container group definition that's in FAILED status. Possible reasons include:

An internal issue prevented Amazon GameLift from creating the container group definition resource. Delete the failed resource and call `CreateContainerGroupDefinition <https://docs.aws.amazon.com/gamelift/latest/apireference/API_CreateContainerGroupDefinition.html>`__again.
An access-denied message means that you don't have permissions to access the container image on ECR. See IAM permission examples for help setting up required IAM permissions for Amazon GameLift.
The ImageUri value for at least one of the containers in the container group definition was invalid or not found in the current Amazon Web Services account.
At least one of the container images referenced in the container group definition exceeds the allowed size. For size limits, see Amazon GameLift endpoints and quotas.
At least one of the container images referenced in the container group definition uses a different operating system than the one defined for the container group.
